Name: Mrs. Ada Wilson
Address: Assiniboia, Saskatchewan

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1893
Where did you get your homesteading land? West Carleton District
Where had you been living before that? Clare, Manitoba (now Alberta)
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 1/2 mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every 6 weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, sugar, flour, oatmeal, salt, prunes, dried apples, syrup, soda, rice.

2. FLours AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Mill's flour
In what quantities did you buy it? 4 quintals
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.20
How much did you use Graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes
For how many years? 1893
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.50
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? None
Farina? None
Oats? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? Crusher

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Mode of transportation, horses, wagons, stone boat sleighs. Now mostly cars.

A pioneer of this Crow Arable drove to Souris with a yoke of oxen, for a great off tour taking two weeks, a distance of about 110 miles. The farmers drew their grain to Alameda & Cypress, a 2 day trip stopping at a halfway house over night sleeping on floors. When beds were full, other farmers took their butter, eggs & went to Moosejaw 60 miles for their supply before any little stores started up.
Always rely on home foods.
